Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> On 1/19/06, Robert Lucente <rlucente@...> wrote:
> >
> > Googled and found http://www.w3.org/DOM/Test/Documents/DOMTSBuild.html.
> >
> > The above states, "If you get a out of memory error (very likely if you
> > build the DOM Level 3 Core tests)". It then recommends "set
> > ANT_OPTS=-Xmx512M". Request that people share how they solved their "out
> > of
> > memory" issue.
>
>
> FYI, we did this in TestNG by allowing @Factories to return either test
> classes or iterators. In the latter case, the iterators are walked one
> element at a time, the yielded elements are considered as test classes (or
> further iterators) and run, and then we move on to the next element.

Let's assume that the problem here is this: JUnit 3, by requiring test 
cases to all be in memory before any running happens, could be used 
fairly memory effectively, but only if:

1) All large TestCase fields were only initialized in setUp
2) All large TestCase fields were set back to null in tearDown

Otherwise, no test cases or fields could be garbage collected, and 
memory usage climbs steadily up as tests are executed.

>
> Some of our users are creating thousands of tests and they were 
> running out
> of memory without this feature. It's marginal, but when you need it, you
> really need it.

In JUnit 4, test fixture objects are created right before execution, and 
no references to test fixture objects are maintained by the framework, 
so that only the currently running test needs to be on the heap. I have 
reason to believe that this will solve the problem you describe above, 
and I'm anxious for people who have had that problem to confirm or 
refute this hope.

I'm a little confused by the TestNG description above. Are you saying 
that you saved memory by lazily classloading? Loading lots of classes 
can be a memory drain--all Java programs have this issue--but I had 
assumed that the goal was reducing the amount of data, not classes, in 
memory.

Thanks,

David Saff
